ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to be a person. How to live life. How to write well in tight elegant prose. What a biography is(?). How to think. These seem general, but it is probably a mark of this class' excellence to tackle general topics so deeply and insightfully!

I learned about the ways in which historical writing is the reconciliation of fact and fiction. l learned how to write clear and engaging historical papers and how to make appointments at and do research with the Yale Archives. I learned how to write with style.

Aside from learning about a great many well-known and unknown figures, we learned how to live our lives with self-awareness and acceptance (of contradictions). I learned how to write, discard, and write anew, and how to focus when a lot of room for creativity is allowed.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Gaddis is one of the kindest and most attentive professors I have met. He asks probing questions, invites us to reconsider our opinions, is really candid and actually very funny. The seminar probably also hinged much on the seminar dynamic, which was pretty amazing this year! I really enjoyed everyone's perspectives. I particularly enjoyed the selection of books. They seemed a random assortment at first, but are definitely books I want to keep on my bookshelf and revisit over and over again!

Doing all the readings is unrealistic. However, the emphasis on studying a different biography each week is effective in making students aware of the range of styles and perspectives on writing biographies. Professor Gaddis facilitates meaningful discussions around historical figures and the study of history while also guiding students to produce high-level, well-written historical papers.

This course requires a lot of reading. A lot a lot of reading. But I also wouldn't get rid of it. It might be helpful to encourage students to relax a little more about reading every word. It's a whirlwind course, but it is so well-taught, and Professor Gaddis gives great insights and fosters student growth. He expects a lot, but that is a definite strength of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar was the best it could be given the circumstances.
The Zoom format was actually quite helpful because Professor Gaddis was available for meetings more often. This could probably be carried over after the pandemic, as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! This is such a fantastic class to read amazing literature with a smart, discerning and student-focused professor.
If you want to read good books, become a better writer, and learn how to use the archives, this is a great course to take.

I would recommend this course to another student who wants to know about how other people lived their lives. This course inevitably seeps into everyday life  the weeks of the semester are partly defined for me by the biographies we read  and it requires deep self-reflection. It's the kind of Yale course that makes you a better person. I'd be careful not to take it with a super busy schedule, but Professor Gaddis is lenient if you ask.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
